choices.text: Aspiration - Super segments of lower lobe involved

questions.text: Incorrect about chest X-ray infiltrate is: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interstitial infiltrate - pyogenic

 

Explanation:


Pyogenic (bacterial) pneumonia typically presents with lobar consolidation rather than interstitial infiltrates. Interstitial infiltrates are more characteristic of atypical pneumonia caused by organisms such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae, viruses, or Legionella species.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspiration - Super segments of lower lobe involved : Can involve both upper and lower lung segments depending on patient positioning.

 

 

Option C. Lymphadenopathy - TB, fungal, or malignancy: Seen in tuberculosis, fungal infections, and malignancies.

 

Option D. Interstitial infiltrate - Atypical pneumonia: Typically associated with viral, atypical bacterial, or chronic lung diseases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyogenic pneumonia presents with lobar consolidation, whereas interstitial infiltrates are seen in atypical pneumonia and viral infections.

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bainbridge reflex

 

Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.

 

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

Option C. Cushing Reflex: Cushing reflex is a protective reflex that helps save the brain tissues from ischemic effects during the periods of reduced cerebral blood flow. It is also called Cushing reaction, response or phenomenon.

 

Option D. J Reflex: Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bainbridge reflex is a cardiovascular reflex that increases heart rate in response to increased venous return, enhancing cardiac output to match the increased blood flow into the heart.

choices.text: Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis
Repair with great saphenous vein graft
Repair with prosthetic graft
Repair with saphenous vein patch

questions.text: A man presented with a history of stab injury over the arm. On examination, there was a hematoma present, and radial and ulnar pulses were not felt. A 3.5 cm longitudinal tear is noted in the brachial artery. Which among the following is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repair with great saphenous vein graft

 

In this patient, who has sustained a long tear to the brachial artery due to a stab injury, the best treatment option is to repair it with a great saphenous vein interposition graft harvested from the patient's uninjured leg.

 

The most desirable graft used is the great saphenous vein. A native vein graft is preferable to a prosthetic graft because:

 

  • Its elastic properties are comparable to that of an artery and enable pulsatile flow.
  • The diameter is similar to that of an extremity artery.
  • It is not thrombogenic and has long-term patency.

 

Other grafts that can be used are cephalic vein, lesser saphenous vein, and prosthetic conduits. However, the great saphenous vein is generally preferred due to better compatibility and long-term outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis: Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis can be done only if the repair is tension-free. If the length of the injured area is long, vessel injuries cannot be repaired by primary end-to-end anastomoses and instead require an interposition graft.

 

Option C. Prosthetic grafts: Prosthetic grafts are only preferred when there has been trauma to the native saphenous vein or when there is a size mismatch. Polyetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) graft is commonly used.

 

Option D. Saphenous vein patch: Saphenous vein patch is used in the closure of the arteriotomy site during carotid endarterectomies and is not suitable for long tears.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For long arterial tears in trauma, such as a stab injury to the brachial artery, using a great saphenous vein graft for repair is preferred due to its compatibility with the native artery's diameter, elasticity, and non-thrombogenic properties.

questions.text: Which of the following colored cannula will you use to achieve maximum flow rate in a patient who needs a large amount of fluids?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grey

 

The grey-colored intravenous cannula, which is 16G, allows a flow rate of 236 ml/min, making it highly suitable for administering large volumes of fluids quickly. It is commonly used in cases such as trauma, major surgery, gastrointestinal bleeding, and situations requiring rapid blood transfusions or fluid replacement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green (18G): The green cannula has a flow rate of 103 ml/min. It is used for blood product transfusions, delivery of irritant medications, and major surgeries, but it is less efficient for rapid fluid administration compared to the grey cannula.

 

Option C. Blue (22G): The blue cannula has a flow rate of 42 ml/min and is suitable for use in small or fragile veins and for cytotoxic therapy. It is not appropriate for situations requiring a large fluid volume due to its significantly lower flow rate.

 

Option D. Pink (20G): The pink cannula, with a flow rate of 67 ml/min, is used for general IV maintenance, antibiotics, and analgesics. Its flow rate is not adequate for high-volume fluid administration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For rapid fluid administration, especially in emergencies or trauma cases, a grey (16G) or orange (14G) cannula should be used to ensure a high flow rate.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

 

The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by the excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the posterior pituitary gland or another source. This excessive release results in water retention and dilutional hyponatremia.

 

Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L: This option is incorrect. In SIADH, urinary sodium is typically high, usually greater than 40 mEq/L, due to the body's inability to excrete water appropriately, which leads to concentrated urine with high sodium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum sodium <135 mEq/L: This option is correct as SIADH commonly presents with hyponatremia (low serum sodium levels) due to the dilution of blood sodium by the retained water.


Option C. Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg: This option is correct. In SIADH, urine osmolality is typically high because the kidneys are concentrating the urine inappropriately due to the persistent effect of ADH.

 

Option D. Patient can be clinically euvolemic: This option is correct. Patients with SIADH often appear clinically euvolemic (normal body fluid volume), as the retained water is distributed evenly throughout the body without significant signs of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is relative bradycardia commonly observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above


Relative bradycardia, also known as Faget's sign, occurs when a patient's heart rate is lower than expected relative to an elevated body temperature. Normally, an increase in body temperature causes the heart rate to increase by approximately 15-20 beats per minute for every 1°C rise. However, in relative bradycardia, this expected increase in heart rate is absent or diminished.

 

Relative bradycardia is not highly sensitive or specific as a diagnostic marker but can be helpful in clinical settings, especially where advanced diagnostic resources are limited.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Typhoid fever:  Caused by Salmonella typhi, typhoid fever is a well-known infectious cause of relative bradycardia.

 

Option B. Q fever:  Caused by Coxiella burnetii, Q fever is another infection linked with relative bradycardia.

 

Option C. Leptospirosis:  Caused by Leptospira interrogans, leptospirosis is also associated with relative bradycardia in certain cases.

 

Educational Objective:


Causes of relative bradycardia:

 

 

Relative bradycardia is often associated with infections caused by organisms that are both gram-negative and intracellular.

questions.text:
Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic drug. It also produces sedation and adverse effects like dry mouth and hypotension. All these actions result due to action on which of the following receptors?(INICET MAY 2024)

 

1. D2 and 5HT2 receptors

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic receptors

3. Muscarinic and alpha-adrenergic receptors

4. H1 receptors
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 3 and 4 are correct

 

Chlorpromazine is a typical anti-psychotic drug having main mechanism of antipsychotic action as D2 blockade and minor as 5 HT2 blockade. However, it also blocks many other receptors that can result in adverse effects.

 

While chlorpromazine does block H1 receptors causing sedation, it is not the sole receptor responsible for its adverse effects. It must be considered in conjunction with D2, 5HT2, muscarinic, and alpha-adrenergic receptors.

 

Other Option:

 

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic Receptors: Chlorpromazine does not primarily act on GABA or beta-adrenergic receptors, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actions of anti-psychotic drugs

 

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/470-471

choices.text: Waxy cast
RBC cast
WBC cast
Maltese cross cast

questions.text: During rounds, you come across the urinalysis report of the 30-year-old male diagnosed with Fabry's disease. What type of urinary casts would you expect to see in the report? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maltese cross cast

 

Maltese cross urinary casts are seen in a patient diagnosed with Fabry's disease.

 

Urine analysis in Fabry's disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a Maltese cross appearance.

 

 

Maltese cross birefringence has also been described in:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans, cholesterol ester storage disease, babesiosis, and in urine sediments of a patient with nephrotic syndrome and erythropoietic protoporphyria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waxy cast: Waxy casts are typically seen in chronic kidney disease and are associated with severe tubular atrophy and stasis of urine flow. They do not exhibit a Maltese cross pattern.

 

Option B. RBC cast: RBC casts are indicative of glomerular injury, such as in glomerulonephritis, and are not associated with Fabry's disease.

 

Option C. WBC cast: WBC casts are typically seen in conditions like pyelonephritis or interstitial nephritis, where there is inflammation involving the renal tubules or interstitium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maltese cross casts in urinalysis are indicative of Fabry's disease due to the presence of glycolipid-laden renal tubular cells. These casts show a characteristic birefringent pattern under polarized light.

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given slide stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute angled branching aspergillus

 

The given slide stained with GMS shows acute-angled (45°) uniform, branching septate hyphae which is suggestive of Aspergillus species.

 

Aspergillus species grow rapidly, producing aerial hyphae that bear characteristic conidial structures. Long aseptate conidiophores are seen with terminal vesicles on which phialides are arranged in basipetal chains.

 

The following image shows LPCB mount of Aspergillus fumigatus showing the long conidiophores with terminal vesicles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obtuse angled mucor: Mucor produces non-septate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium.

 

Option B. Acute angled penicillium: Penicillium produces septate hyphae with branched, septate and brush-like conidiophores.

 

Option D. Obtuse angled Rhizopus: Rhizopus appears similar to Mucor but it has rhizoids with sporangiophores arising in groups directly above the rhizoids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain shows characteristic features of Aspergillus species. These features include acute-angled (45°) uniform branching septate hyphae.

choices.text: a, b and c
d and e
a, d and e
a, b and d

questions.text:
Aspirin and phenobarbitone are acidic drugs whereas diazepam is a basic drug. Which of the following statement/s about these drugs is/are true?(AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. Aspirin is present mainly in non-ionized form in stomach, hence can be easily absorbed
  2. Diazepam is mostly absorbed form intestine
  3. Phenobarbitone can be absorbed from stomach but most of the absorption occurs in small intestine due to its large surface area
  4. No drug is absorbed in large intestine due to its very low surface area
  5. Diseases decreasing the transit time of drugs like diarrhea will increase the drug absorption in small intestine
questions.solution:
Ans. A. a, b and c

 

Absorption across any membrane depends on lipid solubility. Non-ionized form of drugs is lipid soluble and can easily cross the membranes.

 

 

So, basic drugs like diazepam are absorbed maximally from intestine (option b).

 

  • Acidic drugs although are mainly non-ionized in stomach but are absorbed very less because the gastric emptying time is very small. So, these are quickly transferred to intestine. These become ionized in intestine due to alkaline medium. However, due to their longer time of stay in intestine and very large surface area as compared to stomach even the small amount of their non-ionised form contributes to significant absorption. So, practically every drug (whether acidic or basic) are absorbed more in intestine as compared to stomach. 
  • Aspirin (acidic drug) – It is non-ionised in stomach and hence easily absorbed.
  • Diazepam (basic drug)- It is non-ionised in intestine, hence easily absorbed.
  • Phenobarbitone (acidic drug)- Any drug is maximally absorbed in intestine due to large surface area of intestine.
  • Surface area of large intestine is large, so statement (d) is wrong.
  • Diarrhea decreases the transit time of drug, hence decreases the absorption as the time available for absorption decreases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option D. This statement is incorrect. The large intestine does have a considerable surface area and can absorb drugs, although to a lesser extent compared to the small intestine.

 

Option E. This statement is also incorrect. Diseases that decrease the transit time, such as diarrhea, reduce the absorption of drugs because the time available for absorption is decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-ionized forms of drugs are more lipid-soluble and can cross membranes more easily. Acidic drugs like aspirin and phenobarbitone are primarily non-ionized in the stomach but are absorbed mainly in the intestine due to its large surface area. Basic drugs like diazepam are absorbed maximally from the intestine.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/20-21

questions.text: A 60-year-old female is diagnosed with breast cancer. Her tumor is found to be HER2-positive but estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) negative. The tumor was resistant to trastuzumab. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be effective in the treatment of this patient's breast cancer?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lapatinib

 

Lapatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that can be used for the treatment of HER2-positive but trastuzumab-resistant breast cancer. Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that is commonly used for the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer, but some patients may develop resistance to this drug over time. Lapatinib works by targeting the HER2 receptor, which is overexpressed in HER2-positive breast cancer, and can be effective in treating breast cancer that has become resistant to trastuzumab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sorafenib is a kinase inhibitor that is primarily used for the treatment of advanced liver cancer and kidney cancer. It works by blocking the activity of several proteins that promote the growth and spread of cancer cells.

 

Option C. Vismodegib is a hedgehog pathway inhibitor that is used for the treatment of basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer. It works by blocking the hedgehog signalling pathway, which is involved in the development and growth of cancer cells.

 

Option D. Erlotinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that is used for the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer, pancreatic cancer, and other types of cancer. It works by blocking the activity of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which is involved in the growth and spread of cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lapatinib is an effective treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer, especially in cases where the cancer has become resistant to trastuzumab. It works by targeting the HER2 receptor and can help manage this specific type of breast cancer.

choices.text: Pain occurs on walking a fixed distance and is relieved by rest
Pain occurs immediately on standing and improves on bending forward
Pain is worse at night in bed and at rest
Pain occurs on taking the first step

questions.text: Which of these is true about intermittent claudication? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pain occurs on walking a fixed distance and is relieved by rest

 

Intermittent claudication characteristics:

 

  • Pain occurs after walking a predictable distance
  • Distance is relatively fixed for each patient
  • Pain is relieved by rest within minutes
  • Indicates chronic peripheral arterial disease
  • Due to inadequate blood flow during exercise

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pain occurs immediately on standing and improves on bending forward:

 

  • This describes neurogenic claudication
  • Characteristic of lumbar canal stenosis
  • Not related to vascular insufficiency

 

Option C. Pain is worse at night in bed and at rest:

 

  • This describes rest pain
  • Feature of critical limb ischemia
  • Advanced stage of peripheral arterial disease
  • Not intermittent claudication

 

Option D. Pain occurs on taking the first step:

 

  • Feature of neurogenic claudication
  • Seen in spinal canal stenosis
  • Not characteristic of vascular disease

 

Educational Objective: 


Intermittent claudication is characterized by pain occurring after walking a fixed distance and being relieved by rest, similar to angina of the legs.

questions.text: You are the on-call surgeon who is called for an emergency laparotomy for a patient with suspected bowel obstruction. During the surgery, which organ will you first visualize to determine if the obstruction is in the small or large bowel? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caecum

 

  • The caecum is a pouch-like structure at the beginning of the colon. Visualizing the caecum first would indicate that the obstruction likely involves the large bowel if it is distended, helping to differentiate it from a small bowel obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between small and large bowel obstruction in cases of intestinal obstruction.
  • Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement, while collapsed cecum implies small bowel obstruction.
  • Identifying a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment leads to the identification of the cause.

questions.text: A tall 10-year-old boy presents with Sexual Maturity Rating 5 and hyperpigmentation. His BP is 150/100 mm Hg. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

 

The presentation of a tall 10-year-old boy with a Sexual Maturity Rating (SMR) of 5 and hypertension (BP 150/100 mm Hg) indicates precocious puberty. The SMR of 5 typically signifies full sexual maturity, which is unusual for a 10-year-old and suggests precocious puberty.

 

Hyperpigmentation is likely due to elevated ACTH levels, which can occur in congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The key to the diagnosis is understanding the enzyme deficiencies that lead to CAH and their associated symptoms.

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency leads to increased production of 11-deoxycorticosterone, a mineralocorticoid that causes hypertension due to salt retention. This condition also results in excess androgen production, leading to precocious puberty in boys and virilization in girls.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 21β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This is the most common cause of CAH but is typically associated with salt-wasting, not hypertension. It results in increased androgen production leading to virilization and ambiguous genitalia in females, and precocious puberty in males.

 

Option C. 17β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This deficiency is characterized by hypertension and hypokalemia but does not usually cause hyperpigmentation or precocious puberty. It often results in underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option D. SCC (side-chain cleavage) deficiency: This enzyme deficiency leads to a severe form of CAH with salt-wasting and adrenal insufficiency but is not typically associated with hypertension or hyperpigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency in congenital adrenal hyperplasia causes hypertension due to salt retention and precocious puberty due to excess androgen production.

questions.text: Dr. Sunita, a medical officer in a rural health clinic, is tasked with ensuring the potency and safety of vaccines. She comes across several vaccine vials, each with a Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) attached. The VVMs change color to indicate the cumulative exposure of the vaccine to heat, thus helping in determining the viability of the vaccine. She notices varying degrees of color changes across these VVMs. Given this scenario, which of the following choices correctly identifies which vaccine vials, based on the observed VVM color changes, should be considered safe for use? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Vials 1 and 2 can be used

 

  • Based on the image provided, it's evident that only vials 1 and 2 are suitable for use because the inner squares of these vials color lighter than the outer circles.
  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.
  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.
  • Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.
  • If the square and the circle are the same in colour, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the marked bond in Orange? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrogen bond

 

Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is composed of four deoxyribonucleotides, i.e. deoxyadenylate (A), deoxyguanylate (G), deoxycytidylate (C), and thymidylate (T).

 

These units are linked by 3′ to 5′ phosphodiester bonds (covalent bonds) to form a long polypeptide chain. The nucleotide is formed by a combination of base + sugar + phosphoric acid. The 3′-hydroxyl of one sugar is linked to the 5′-hydroxyl of another sugar through a phosphate group.

 

The DNA strands are held together mainly by hydrogen bonds between the purine and pyrimidine bases. There are two hydrogen bonds between Adenine (A) and Thymine (T) while there are three hydrogen bonds between Cytidine (C) and Guanine (G). The GC bond is therefore stronger than the AT bond.

 

The spatial alignment of the helix allows only purine to pyrimidine base pairing.

 

A-T and C-G base pairs have almost the same shape. A mispairing will disturb the stable double helical structure.

 

 

Other interactions contributing to DNA stability include:

 

  • Hydrophobic effects - DNA has an arrangement wherein the non-polar, uncharged bases are present in the interior of the structure, while the negatively charged phosphates are present on the outside. As the cellular environment is aqueous and polar, the hydrophobic bases in the interior of the helix are kept away from the surrounding water and the hydrophilic heads are exposed and interact with the exterior water. This property increases the solubility of DNA in water.
  • Van der Waals forces - The nitrogenous bases stacked upon one another are spaced based on their van der Waals distance. Van der Waals distance is the distance at which two molecules are attracted to each other. If this distance reduces, the electrons of the two molecules may overlap causing repulsion. These forces are very distance dependent and are inversely proportional to the sixth power of distance (r6). Although a single van der Waals interaction has a very small effect on the overall structure of DNA, the net effect of several interactions leads to substantial stability.
  • Ionic interactions - The electrostatic (ion-ion) repulsion of the negatively charged phosphates on the outside can make DNA potentially very unstable. However, magnesium ions (Mg2+) and cationic proteins along with arginine and lysine residues interact with the negatively charged groups in the DNA and stabilize it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. lonic bond: This type of bond occurs between charged atoms (ions), typically in the form of salts and is not involved in the structure of DNA.


Option B. Covalent bond: Covalent bonds are strong bonds formed by sharing electrons between atoms. In DNA, covalent bonds (phosphodiester bonds) link the sugar-phosphate backbone but are not marked in the provided image.

option D. Phosphodiester Bond: This is a covalent bond that forms the sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA. It is not the bond marked in orange in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrogen bonds between purine and pyrimidine bases stabilize the double helix structure of DNA.

questions.text: You are attending physiology viva. The examiner asks you who recorded the first EEG. You say "I don't know "The examiner feels bad for you and gives you a clue that "the name sounds like something you get commonly in McDonalds". You remember the name and answer correctly. What type of memory has been implicated here?" (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Priming

 

Priming is when exposure to a stimulus influences the response to a subsequent stimulus. In this scenario, the examiner's hint about McDonald's (suggesting "burger") facilitated the student's recall of "Berger," who recorded the first EEG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semantic memory: Semantic memory involves facts and general knowledge, like knowing the capital of a country.

 

Option B. Implicit memory: Implicit memory is unconscious, but involves skills or tasks, like riding a bike.

 

Option C. Associative learning: Associative learning involves pairing two stimuli, like Pavlov's dog experiment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Priming means that a recent experience makes it easier for you to notice or identify something related.

 

Perceptual Priming: Recognizing something becomes easier because you've recently seen something that looks similar. For example, if you've just seen a picture of a lion, you'll be faster at spotting the word "lion" even if it's a bit unclear.

 

Conceptual Priming: Understanding or noticing something becomes easier because you've recently thought about a related idea. For example, if you've just read about rivers and banks, you'll probably guess the word "bank" when given "ban_" instead of thinking of "band."

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 116.

questions.text:
True statements about fracture shaft of femur: (AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. More commonly in elderly.
  2. Easily managed with Gallow’s traction in elderly.
  3. Associated with pulmonary complications.
  4. Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. c & d are correct

 

FRACTURE SHAFT FEMUR

 

  • Men are more likely to sustain a fracture between the ages of 15 to 35, while women begin to show a steady increase starting at age 60.
  • Men are more likely to sustain fracture from automobile accidents or other high-energy mechanisms.
  • Women are more likely to sustain an fracture from ground-level falls.
  • Automobile accidents are more prevalent in the younger population, while ground-level falls are more common in the elderly population, which is attributed to osteoporosis.
  • Treatment:

 

 

a. Management Plan of Fracture Shaft Femur in Adults: 

  1. Interlock intramedullary nailing currently is considered to be the treatment of choice for most femoral shaft fractures.
  2. External fixator is used in open fractures (open injuries).
  3. Delayed union is treated by dynamization of nail (removal of proximal or distal screws or both) and bone grafting.
  4. Non-union is treated by exchange nailing (i.e. introduction of large diameter reamed interlocking nail) and bone grafting.

 

b. Management Plan in children:

  1. Gallow’s traction: < 2 years of age and traction weight < 2 kg of weight can be used.
  2. Immediate or early spica casting is the treatment of choice in children <5 years of age for femoral fractures with < 2–3 cm of initial shortening, and stable fracture pattern.
  3. Femoral fractures with > 2-3 cm of shortening or marked instability, high probability of slipping of reduction and tight thigh swelling in 6 months to 5 years age group, who cannot be reduced with immediate spica casting, require 3-10 days of skin or skeletal traction before casting.
  4. Fixation by enders intramedullary flexible rods and plating can be used in children with multiple trauma, head injury, vascular compromise, floating knee injuries or multiple fracture, preferably in children > 6 years of age.

 

  • Complications:
    • Postoperative complications include fat emboli syndrome, pulmonary embolism, infection, osteomyelitis, malunion, nonunion, and hip and knee pain.
    • Nerve injuries are common and can be due to positioning as well as iatrogenic injury. Pudendal nerve injuries occur from positioning patients with a perineal post. The sciatic nerve can suffer injury in retrograde nailing with excessive traction of the lower extremity or surgical instruments. 
    • Vascular injury to the DFA or SFA can occur after penetration with instruments or implants.
    • Intraoperative fractures may occur, especially of the greater trochanter, the knee.
    • Malrotation is one of the most significant complications. Malrotation of greater than 14 degrees from neutral can alter gait mechanics and efficiency. Patients cope better with internal than with external malalignment.
    • Nonunion is a failure of the fracture to heal or lack of signs of healing for six months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Femoral shaft fractures are more commonly seen in young males of age 15-35 years.
  • It is easily managed with intramedullary nailing in elderly.
  • It is most commonly associated with pulmonary complications like pulmonary embolism.
  • Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management in adult patients.

questions.text: What is the repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-homologous end joining

 

NHEJ is the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9. When CRISPR-Cas9 induces double-strand breaks in DNA, NHEJ rejoins the broken DNA ends, often introducing insertions or deletions (indels) at the repair site. This can result in gene knockout or disruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision repair (BER): BER is a DNA repair mechanism that corrects damaged or mismatched bases in the DNA. It primarily deals with single-base changes and small DNA lesions. CRISPR-Cas9, on the other hand, creates double-strand breaks, so BER is not directly involved in repairing these breaks.

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair (NER): NER is another DNA repair mechanism that mainly deals with the removal of larger DNA lesions, such as those caused by UV radiation. It is not the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9-induced double-strand breaks.

 

Option D. Mismatch repair (MMR): MMR is a repair mechanism that corrects errors in DNA replication, specifically base-pair mismatches and small insertion-deletion loops. It is not the primary mechanism involved in repairing double-strand breaks created by CRISPR-Cas9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9 is non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), which repairs double-strand breaks by ligating the broken DNA ends, potentially causing insertions or deletions that disrupt the target gene.

questions.text: La belle indifference is seen in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conversion disorder

 

La Belle indifference can be seen in Conversion disorder.

 

CONVERSION DISORDER

 

ICD-11 uses the term ‘dissociative neurological symptom disorder’

 

  • Patients present with symptoms suggestive of motor, sensory or cognitive deficits; however, no neurological cause can be found.
  • Also, the symptoms do not conform to the anatomical and physiological principles

 

Patients may have ‘la belle indifference’, which is a lack of concern for the symptoms. E.g., A patient with sudden onset loss of vision in an eye may appear unconcerned with her symptom.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing populations targeted by the HIV sentinel surveillance program. Which group is NOT traditionally included in HIV sentinel surveillance? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) STD clinic attendees

 

  • Routine monitoring for HIV is generally not conducted among individuals visiting STD clinics.
  • Sentinel surveillance serves to enhance the existing notification systems employed for disease surveillance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single male migrants: Included in sentinel surveillance as they are considered at high risk.

 

Option B. Truck drivers: Included due to their high-risk behavior.

 

Option D. Antenatal women: Included to monitor HIV prevalence among pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sites for HIV sentinel surveillance includes:

 

  • A pregnant woman of reproductive age and attending the antenatal clinic for the first time.
  • Female sex workers.
  • Hijra/Transgenders.
  • IV drug users
  • Truckers.
  • Homosexual Men
  • Migrants.

choices.text: Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease
Calcification of valve; Mitral stenosis

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dyspnea on exertion for 1 month. Echocardiography showed the presence of mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy. Identify the histopathological finding given below and the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease

 

The lesion shown in the histopathological slide is Aschoff's body and the most probable diagnosis is rheumatic heart disease (RHD).

 

Aschoff's bodies have the following components:

 

  • Anitschkow cells or plump macrophages
  • Abundant cytoplasm
  • Caterpillar cells - refer to centrally condensed chromatin into slender, wavy ribbons
  • Foci of fibrinoid necrosis
  • Aschoff's giant cells - multinucleated larger macrophages
  • T-cells
  • Plasma cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcification of valve; Mitral stenosis: While mitral stenosis can result from calcification, it is more typically associated with chronic rheumatic heart disease, which involves Aschoff bodies rather than calcification alone.

 

Option C. Granuloma; Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas, but it does not present with Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D. Non-caseating granuloma: Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis typically presents with caseating granulomas, not Aschoff bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies are indicative of Rheumatic heart disease (RHD), and their presence supports the diagnosis in a patient with clinical features such as mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1044

questions.text: In a study involving radiographic evaluations, two physicians independently assessed 100 chest X-rays. They calculated a Kappa statistic of 0.71 to measure inter-rater agreement. What does this Kappa value indicate about the level of agreement between the two doctors? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Substantial

 

Explanation:

 

The Kappa statistic is used to measure the degree of agreement between two raters beyond what would be expected by chance. Here's what each value typically indicates about the level of agreement:

 

A. Slight: A Kappa value from 0.01 to 0.20. This range indicates that there is minimal agreement between the two raters, barely above what would be expected by random chance.

 

B. Fair: A Kappa value from 0.21 to 0.40. This suggests there is some agreement between the raters, but it remains relatively low.

 

C. Moderate: A Kappa value from 0.41 to 0.60. This level indicates a moderate amount of agreement, showing that the raters often agree on their assessments.

 

D. Substantial: A Kappa value from 0.61 to 0.80. This indicates a high level of agreement, suggesting that the raters consistently agree in their assessments most of the time.

 

E. Near Perfect agreement – kappa value from 0.81 to 0.99

 

F. Perfect agreement – Kappa value – 1.00

 

In this  case, a Kappa value of 0.71 falls within the "Substantial" category, indicating a strong and consistent level of agreement between the two physicians assessing the chest X-rays. This is generally considered an excellent result in clinical settings, as it shows that both observers have a similar interpretation of the radiographic images, which can greatly improve diagnostic accuracy and patient care.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The Kappa statistic is a reliable tool for assessing the consistency and reliability of diagnostic interpretations between different raters, especially in medical imaging where subjective judgment can vary.
  • High Kappa values, like 0.71, reinforce the reliability of the assessments and the potential for standardized approaches in clinical practice

questions.text: Which fusion exocytosis complex is affected in tetanus?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synaptobrevin

 

Synaptobrevin, also known as VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein), is one of the proteins involved in the SNARE complex, which plays a crucial role in mediating vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release at the synaptic cleft. In tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin specifically targets and cleaves synaptobrevin, preventing the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like GABA and glycine. This leads to muscle hyperactivity and spastic paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Snap 25: SNAP-25 (synaptosomal-associated protein 25) is another component of the SNARE complex involved in neurotransmitter release. It is not directly targeted by the tetanus neurotoxin.

 

Option C. Syntaxin: Syntaxin is a third component of the SNARE complex, and like SNAP-25, it is not the primary target of the tetanus neurotoxin.

 

Option D. Synaptophysin: Synaptophysin is a synaptic vesicle membrane protein, but it is not directly involved in the SNARE complex or the process of exocytosis. It is not affected by the tetanus neurotoxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical students should understand that in tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin targets and affects synaptobrevin (VAMP), disrupting the SNARE complex and inhibiting the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters, leading to muscle hyperactivity and spastic paralysis. This knowledge is important for understanding the pathophysiology of tetanus.

 

The light chain of tetanospasmin cleave the Gln76-Phe77 bond of synaptobrevin which is an integral V-SNARE necessary for vesicle fusion to membranes in CNS and thus by cleaving this SNARE, TeNT has the effect of interfering with exocytosis of neurotransmitters such as γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glycine from inhibitory interneurons causing violent spastic paralysis.

 

Ref- Ananthanarayan and Paniker 10th e/p 265

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is independently true, but the Reason is independently false
Assertion is independently false, but the Reason is independently true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Central dogma says DNA is transcribed into RNA, which is subsequently translated into proteins.


Reason (R): Retrovirus has reverse transcriptase of central dogma where RNA is first converted into DNA, which is then transcribed to RNA, which is subsequently translated into proteins.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reason are independently true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion


The assertion correctly states the central dogma of molecular biology, which describes the flow of genetic information. It outlines three primary processes:

 

  1. Replication: The DNA molecule is copied to produce an identical daughter DNA strand.
  2. Transcription: DNA is transcribed into RNA.
  3. Translation: RNA is translated into proteins.

 

The central dogma represents the unidirectional flow of genetic information, from DNA to RNA and then to proteins.

 

The reason provided describes an extension of the central dogma, applicable to retroviruses. Retroviruses, like HIV, possess the enzyme reverse transcriptase, which synthesizes DNA from an RNA template. This process deviates from the typical flow outlined in the central dogma but is a unique mechanism seen in certain viruses. While both the assertion and reason are true, the reason does not directly explain the central dogma but rather provides an exception to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The central dogma of molecular biology describes the flow of genetic information as DNA → RNA → Proteins. Retroviruses, however, exhibit reverse transcription, an exception to this classical concept.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented with a painless breast lump measuring 6.2 X 4.5 cm in the left upper outer quadrant and no axillary nodes. Core cut biopsy showed ductal carcinoma in situ. She underwent tumor resection with adequate margins and postoperative H&E showed DCIS with intermediate-grade necrosis and with 6-mm clearance on margins. What would be the next step in treatment? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

According to Silverstein Van Nuys prognostic index which is used for DCIS, the total score is 9, and the patient would require adjuvant radiotherapy.

 

Age: 43 years (score 2), size: 62mm (score 3), clearance margin: 6mm (score 2) with intermediate-grade necrosis (score 2).

 

The Silverstein Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a prognostic tool used in the management of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of the breast. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and the VNPI helps guide treatment decisions by assessing the risk of local recurrence.

 

The VNPI combines three significant predictors of local recurrence:

 

  1. Tumor size: The size of the DCIS lesion.
  2. Margin width: The width of clear tissue margins around the tumor after surgical resection.
  3. Pathologic classification: The histopathological characteristics of the DCIS, including features like grade and necrosis.

 

Scores on the VNPI typically range from 1 (best prognosis) to 3 (worst prognosis), with higher scores indicating a higher risk of local recurrence

 

The VNPI assists oncologists and surgeons in determining the appropriate treatment approach for patients with DCIS. For example, patients with a lower VNPI score may be candidates for less aggressive treatment, while those with a higher score may require more intensive therapies such as radiation therapy or mastectomy.

 

Score <7: No further treatment

 

Score 7-9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

Score >9: Simple mastectomy

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect associated with the long-term use of intermittent teriparatide for the treatment of osteoporosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) used as an anabolic (bone-building) agent in the treatment of osteoporosis. It is administered via daily subcutaneous injections. While effective in increasing bone mass and reducing fracture risk, the long-term use of teriparatide has been associated with certain risks.

 

Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that has been linked to the long-term use of teriparatide in animal studies. Specifically, when used for more than two years, there is evidence from these studies suggesting an increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. This potential risk has led to a restriction on the duration of teriparatide therapy to a maximum of two years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteonecrosis of the jaw bone: This condition is a known adverse effect of bisphosphonates, not teriparatide. Bisphosphonates can lead to decreased blood flow to the jawbone, causing osteonecrosis, especially following dental procedures.

 

Option C. Subtrochanteric fracture (atypical femoral fracture): This type of fracture is also associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates, rather than teriparatide. Bisphosphonates may alter bone remodeling, leading to atypical fractures.

 

Option D. Loss of bone mass: Teriparatide is an anabolic agent that actually increases bone mass. Bisphosphonates also prevent bone mass loss by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. Thus, loss of bone mass is not associated with either teriparatide or bisphosphonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The long-term use of teriparatide is associated with an increased risk of osteosarcoma, which is why its use is limited to a maximum of two years.

choices.text: Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile
Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in umbilical artery

questions.text: All are criteria of IUGR except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine A PI < 95%

 

Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR) is a condition where a fetus is smaller than expected for the number of weeks of pregnancy. It can result from various factors, including placental insufficiency, maternal health issues, or genetic conditions. Several criteria are commonly used to diagnose IUGR:

 

  • Abdominal circumference < 3rd percentile: This is a common marker used in the assessment of IUGR. A small abdominal circumference indicates that the fetus might not be growing adequately.
  • Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile: Like abdominal circumference, if the estimated fetal weight is below the 3rd percentile, it is a strong indicator of IUGR.
  • Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound that indicates severe placental insufficiency. It is associated with increased risk of adverse perinatal outcomes.

 

However, the option "Uterine A PI < 95%" refers to the uterine artery pulsatility index (PI), which is a measure of the resistance in the uterine artery. In cases of IUGR, resistance is typically high, leading to a high PI, not low. Therefore, a PI < 95% (indicating low resistance) would not be consistent with IUGR. This is why this option is incorrect.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Abdominal circumference < 3rd percentile: This is a valid criterion used in the assessment of IUGR.

 

Option B. Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile: This criterion is also used in the diagnosis of IUGR.

 

Option C. Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: This is a critical sign of severe IUGR and is often associated with poor perinatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uterine artery pulsatility index (PI) is typically high in cases of IUGR due to increased resistance. A low PI (< 95%) would not indicate IUGR, making it the incorrect option in this contex

questions.text: A young girl presents with retention of urine and cyclical abdominal pain. On examination, there is a tense bluish bulge seen at the introitus. The diagnosis is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imperforate hymen

 

An imperforate hymen is a congenital disorder where the hymen, a thin membrane that typically surrounds or partially covers the vaginal opening, completely obstructs the vaginal opening. This condition can lead to the accumulation of menstrual blood within the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), resulting in cyclical abdominal pain and urinary retention due to pressure on the bladder.

 

The classic presentation includes:

 

  • Cyclical abdominal pain: This occurs as menstrual blood accumulates but cannot exit the body, leading to distension and discomfort.
  • Retention of urine: The accumulated blood can exert pressure on the bladder and urethra, causing difficulty in urination.
  • Tense bluish bulge at the introitus: This is a distinctive finding in imperforate hymen, where the accumulated blood stretches the hymen, causing it to appear bluish and bulging at the vaginal opening.

 

The treatment for an imperforate hymen typically involves making a cruciate incision in the hymen to drain the accumulated blood (hematocolpos) and relieve the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse vaginal septum: This condition involves a fibrous or muscular wall across the vagina, which can also cause symptoms similar to an imperforate hymen, such as hematocolpos and urinary retention. However, it does not usually present with the characteristic tense bluish bulge at the introitus because the septum is thicker and the blood does not push against the hymen.

 

Option C. Vertical vaginal septum: A vertical vaginal septum is a partition that divides the vaginal canal into two parts. While it may lead to reproductive issues or dyspareunia, it typically does not cause urinary retention or cyclical pain as described in this case, nor does it present with a bluish bulge.

 

Option D. Mullerian agenesis: This is a congenital absence of the uterus, cervix, and upper part of the vagina. Patients with this condition often present with primary amenorrhea but do not typically have cyclical abdominal pain or urinary retention. Additionally, there would be no bluish bulge at the introitus because there is no accumulation of blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of cyclical abdominal pain, urinary retention, and a tense bluish bulge at the introitus in a young girl strongly suggests an imperforate hymen. Early diagnosis and surgical intervention can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

choices.text: If a and c are correct
If a, b and c are correct
a, b, c, & d are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following is correctly matched?

 

  1. Oxygen: Simple Diffusion
  2. Glucose: facilitated diffusion
  3. Na-dependent Calcium: Active transport
  4. Na: Secondary Active transport
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, b, c, & d are correct

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Oxygen: Simple Diffusion: Oxygen is transported by simple passive diffusion based on the concentration gradient. This process does not require any energy input and relies on the natural movement of oxygen molecules from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.

 

Option B. Glucose: facilitated diffusion: Glucose is transported by facilitated diffusion using glucose transporters (GLUTs) and also through Na-dependent transport using sodium-glucose co-transporters (SGLT). GLUTs facilitate glucose transport without energy, while SGLT uses the sodium gradient to transport glucose into cells.

 

Option C. Na-dependent Calcium: Active transport: Calcium is transported by active transport mechanisms, which require energy. These mechanisms include:

  1. Plasma membrane Ca2+ ATPase (PMCA), which pumps calcium out of the cell.
  2. Sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX), which exchanges intracellular calcium for extracellular sodium. Additionally, calcium can be transported via receptor-mediated mechanisms, such as the IP3 receptor, facilitating calcium transport from the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) to the mitochondria.

 

Option D. Na: Secondary Active transport: Sodium often moves down its gradient, but it is also involved in secondary active transport to drive uptake of other substances against their gradients (e.g., glucose in intestines).
The Na⁺/glucose symporter (SGLT) is a classic example.
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each substance (oxygen, glucose, calcium, and sodium) has specific and correct transport mechanisms: oxygen by simple diffusion, glucose by facilitated and Na-dependent transport, calcium by active transport, and sodium by secondary active transport.

 

Reference: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-639

questions.text: The punishment for the death of a patient by spurious drug? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Life imprisonment 

 

  • The punishment for the death of a patient by a spurious drug is life imprisonment as it leads to grievous hurt which is punishable by life imprisonment as per Drugs and Cosmetics act.
  • Spurious or imitation drug products are drug formulations manufactured. concealing the true identity of the product and made to resemble another drug, especially some popular brand, to deceive the buyer and cash on the popularity of original product.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, the distribution of spurious drugs that result in death constitutes grievous hurt, warranting severe legal consequences including life imprisonment.

choices.text: Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG
Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan

questions.text: 50-year-old obese female presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. The physician suspects acute cholecystitis and orders imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is not true about acute cholecystitis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan.

 

This statement is not true. In a Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid (HIDA) scan, the gallbladder is not preferentially visualized in acute cholecystitis. Instead, one of the hallmark findings in acute cholecystitis on a HIDA scan is non-visualization of the gallbladder due to inflammation and obstruction of the cystic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG: This statement is true and is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. On ultrasound (USG), a thickened gallbladder wall, typically greater than 3 mm, is indicative of inflammation and is a characteristic feature of acute cholecystitis.

 

Option B. Murphy's sign positive: This statement is true. Murphy's sign is a clinical maneuver used to assess for acute cholecystitis. It involves palpation of the right upper quadrant during inspiration, and if the patient experiences pain or stops breathing due to pain during this maneuver, it is considered a positive Murphy's sign, suggesting inflammation of the gallbladder.

 

Option C. Leukocytosis: This statement is true. Acute cholecystitis is associated with an inflammatory response, leading to an elevation in white blood cell count, which is known as leukocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute cholecystitis is a common condition characterized by inflammation of the gallbladder, typically due to the presence of gallstones obstructing the cystic duct. Clinical features of acute cholecystitis include right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. A positive Murphy's sign is right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation. On ultrasound imaging, gall bladder thickness >3 mm is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. The HIDA scan is a diagnostic tool for acute cholecystitis, showing non-visualization of the gall bladder 3 hours after radioisotope administration. Preferential visualization of the gall bladder on a HIDA scan is not a feature of acute cholecystitis. It is important to diagnose and treat acute cholecystitis promptly to prevent complications such as gallbladder perforation or gangrene.

questions.text:
A diabetic, hypertensive, and post-MI patient on atorvastatin, metoprolol, and aspirin has lipid profile results of total cholesterol: 238 mg/dL, triglycerides: 125 mg/dL, HDL: 50 mg/dL, and LDL: 160 mg/dL. Which additional medications should be considered to optimize lipid management in this patient? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Bemepedoic acid
  2. Ezetimibe
  3. Gemfibrozil
  4. Evolocumab
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Explanation: 


The patient has elevated total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol with normal triglycerides and HDL. Therefore, drugs targeting cholesterol reduction would be most appropriate:

 

1. Bempedoic acid inhibits ATP citrate lyase, reducing cholesterol synthesis

 

2. Ezetimibe inhibits intestinal cholesterol absorption

 

4. Evolocumab (PCSK9 inhibitor) increases LDL receptor availability, enhancing LDL clearance All these mechanisms would help lower the elevated LDL and total cholesterol levels.

 

Other Option: 
 

3. Gemfibrozil is incorrect as fibrates primarily target high triglycerides, which are normal in this patient (125 mg/dL).

 

Educational Objective: 
 

Lipid-lowering medications based on the specific lipid abnormality: statins, PCSK9 inhibitors, ezetimibe, and bempedoic acid for elevated cholesterol/LDL; fibrates primarily for elevated triglycerides.

choices.text: Denotes latent CMV infection
Denotes chronic CMV infection with immunity to other serotypes
Indicates acute CMV infection
IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anti-CMV IgG antibodies? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

 

IgG avidity assays measure the binding strength between IgG antibodies and virus that can help distinguish a primary CMV infection from a past infection. Following primary CMV infection, IgG antibodies have low binding strength (low avidity) then over 2-4 months mature to high binding strength (high avidity). 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Denotes latent CMV infection: While the presence of anti-CMV IgG antibodies indicates a past infection and potential latent infection, it does not specifically denote the current state of latency.

 

Option B. Denotes chronic CMV infection with immunity to other serotypes: Anti-CMV IgG antibodies indicate past exposure and potential latent infection but do not confer immunity to all serotypes of CMV.

 

Option C. Indicates acute CMV infection: The presence of anti-CMV IgG antibodies alone does not indicate an acute infection; it suggests past exposure. Acute CMV infection is usually indicated by the presence of anti-CMV IgM antibodies or a significant rise in IgG levels over time.

 

Educational objective

 

An IgG avidity assay is a useful tool to differentiate between a primary CMV infection and a past infection. Low avidity IgG indicates a recent infection, whereas high avidity IgG indicates a past infection.

choices.text: MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct

questions.text: Thrombolysis can be considered in all of these conditions, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood pressure of > 185/110 mmHg

 

Blood pressure of > 185/110 mmHg: This is a contraindication for thrombolysis. Elevated blood pressure increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications during thrombolysis. Therefore, blood pressure must be controlled to below 185/110 mmHg before initiating thrombolytic therapy.

 

Thrombolysis is a treatment used to dissolve blood clots in certain types of stroke patients. It is most effective when administered within a specific time window from the onset of symptoms and under certain conditions to ensure patient safety and efficacy of the treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct: This indicates that the infarct size is within a range that is generally considered safe for thrombolysis. More extensive infarcts (> 1/3rd of the middle cerebral artery territory) are a contraindication due to the higher risk of hemorrhagic transformation.

 

Option C. Ischemia < 2 hours and D. Onset of symptoms < 4 hours: Both of these options fall within the critical time window for thrombolysis, which is generally considered up to 4.5 hours from symptom onset. Treatment within this time frame can significantly improve outcomes in stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrombolysis is contraindicated in patients with blood pressure higher than 185/110 mmHg at the time of treatment.

choices.text: BCG, DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles - 1, Vit. A -1

questions.text: A pediatrician in a remote village encounters an 18-month-old child with no vaccination history. According to the National Immunization Schedule, which set of vaccines should the child receive? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles -1, Vit. A - 1

 

  • According to India's National Immunization Schedule (NIS), an 18-month-old child who has not received any immunizations should be given their initial doses of DPT, OPV, measles vaccine, and vitamin A.

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case studies

questions.text: A 26-year-old female suffers a proximal 1/3rd Femoral shaft fracture. What would be the ideal treatment option?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intramedullary nailing

 

FEMORAL SHAFT FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Treatment of femoral shaft fractures can be operative or non-operative.
  • Operative fixation with intramedullary nailing is the gold standard treatment.
  • Other operative techniques include plate osteosynthesis and external fixation.
  • Closed treatment with traction, splinting, and casting may be temporary treatment.

 

Intramedullary Nailing

 

  • Intramedullary nailing (IMN) is the gold standard of treatment for femoral shaft fractures.
  • Early treatment in a stable patient within 24-48 hours reduces the incidence of pulmonary complications, infection, and mortality.
  • Delayed treatment increases pulmonary complications in up to 56% of patients compared to only 16% of patients treated early.
  • The insertion site of an IMN is outside the zone of injury, preserving the surrounding blood flow and retain the hematoma that contains beneficial bone growth factors.
  • It provides a strong and stable internal fixation that allows for early mobilization and weight-bearing, which is crucial for promoting healing and preventing complications.
  • It is a minimally invasive surgical procedure compared to other options like plate fixation, resulting in less tissue disruption and blood loss.
  • It helps in a faster recovery time and a quicker return to daily activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hip Spica: This is a cast that extends from the waist to the toes and is not typically used for femoral shaft fractures due to the limited mobility it allows.

 

Option B. Above Knee Slab: An above-knee slab is a temporary cast that can be used for pain management and swelling reduction but doesn't provide enough stability for healing a fractured femoral shaft.

 

Option C. Above Knee Cast: Similar to an above-knee slab, a cast offers limited stability and wouldn't be suitable for the long-term treatment of this fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramedullary nailing is the treatment option of choice in proximal femoral shaft fractures as it is minimally invasive and provides faster recovery.

questions.text: Drug with mechanism of action are given in two columns. Which of the following is the correct match?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-E

 

The correct matches between the drugs and their mechanisms of action are as follows:

  1. Omalizumab - Anti-IgE (1-C)
    • Indication: Omalizumab is used in the treatment of bronchial asthma. It works by binding to IgE, which plays a key role in allergic reactions.
  2. Itolizumab - Anti-CD 6 (2-A)
    • Indication: Itolizumab is a new drug used for psoriasis. It targets CD6, a molecule involved in T-cell activation.
  3. Daclizumab - Anti-CD 25 (3-B)
    • Indication: Daclizumab acts as an IL-2 receptor antagonist by binding to CD25, which is part of the IL-2 receptor. It is used as an immunosuppressant.
  4. Belimumab - Anti-B lymphocyte stimulator (BlyS) (4-E)
    • Indication: Belimumab is used for the treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It inhibits B-lymphocyte stimulator, which is involved in the survival of B cells.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Reference: KDT 8TH/251-52,943

questions.text: Match the following:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

1-b: Colour vision - Ishihara chart:

 

Colour vision is tested with Ishihara plates, which is a pseudoisochromatic chart. There are patterns of coloured and grey dots that reveal one pattern to persons with normal colour vision and another to those with the colour deficiency.

 

The below image shows a representative plate of the Ishihara chart.

 

 

Limitation of ischihara chart: Ischihara chart is useful as a screening tool for colour blindness. It mainly tests for red-green blindness.

 

In order to check blue-yellow blindness other tests such as 100 Hue Test are required.

 

2-a: Intraocular pressure - Applanation tonometer:

 

An applanation tonometer is used to measure the intraocular pressure. It is based on the Imbert-Fick law, which states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening (A).

 

P = W/A

 

The following is an image of the applanation tonometer:

 

 

There are two types of applanation tonometers:

 

(1) In which the surface area of the prism is constant – Eg

 

  1. Goldmann Applanation Tonometer (GAT):
    • The Goldmann tonometer is one of the most widely used and considered the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure.
    • It consists of a prism that is gently applied to the anesthetized cornea, flattening a small area.
    • The amount of force required to flatten the cornea is directly related to intraocular pressure.
  2. Perkins Applanation Tonometer:
    • The Perkins tonometer is a handheld, portable device used for measuring intraocular pressure.
    • It is similar in principle to the Goldmann tonometer but is more compact and easier to transport.
  3. Tono-Pen (Reichert Tonometer):
    • The Tono-Pen is a handheld electronic applanation tonometer.
    • It works by measuring the force required to flatten the cornea, and the reading is displayed electronically.
    • It is often used in clinical settings due to its ease of use and portability.

 

(2) Tonometer with constant pressure and variable area – eg. MALAKOFF’S Tonometer.

 

3-d: Peripheral vision - Perimetry:

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic procedure used to chart the boundaries of a person's visual field. There are two main types of perimetry: kinetic and static perimetry. Kinetic perimetry involves moving a target with a specific luminance from a non-seeing area in the periphery towards the center until the person perceives it. In contrast, static perimetry involves presenting a stationary stimulus and adjusting its intensity until the person either reaches a threshold of detection or can no longer detect it. One type of static perimetry is tangent screen perimetry, which tests the central 30 degrees field at 1 meter and evaluates a person's central vision.

 

Examples of Kinetic Perimetry – Goldmann perimetry and Bjerrum Perimetry

 

Examples of Static Perimetry – Static Automated perimetry – Humphrey Visual Field analyser and Octopus Visual field analyser.

 

4-c: Central vision - Tangent screen test:

 

The tangent screen test is a specific method used to assess central visual field up to 30 degrees from fixation. It involves using a black screen and white or colored targets to determine the sensitivity of central vision, particularly useful in detecting central visual field defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Colour vision - Ishihara chart
  • Intraocular pressure - Applanation tonometer
  • Peripheral vision - Perimetry
  • Central vision - Tangent screen test

choices.text: Is both intra and extra cellular
Can fuse with other organelles directly
Fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome
Is a single membrane structure

questions.text: What can be the mechanism by which phagolysosome cause cell death in autophagy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome

 

Phagolysosome cause cell death by fusing with lysosome to form autophagolysosome.

 

Autophagy refers to lysosomal digestion of the cell’s own components. It is a survival mechanism in times of nutrient deprivation, so a cell can thrive by recycling its own contents.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Is both intra and extracellular: Autophagy is an intracellular process, not extracellular. It involves the internal digestion of cellular components and does not occur outside the cell.

 

Option B. Can fuse with other organelles directly: While autophagic vacuoles can engulf other organelles, the crucial step in autophagy involves the fusion with a lysosome to form the autophagolysosome, where degradation occurs.

 

Option D. Is a single membrane structure: The autophagic vacuole is initially a double-membrane structure that eventually fuses with a lysosome. The formation of the autophagolysosome is key to the degradation process in autophagy.

 

Educational Objective:


The fusion of an autophagic vacuole with a lysosome to form an autophagolysosome is a central step in the autophagy process, enabling the degradation and recycling of cellular components.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 72

choices.text: ER+, PR+, HER2- High Ki67
ER+, PR+, HER2- Low Ki67
ER+, PR+, HER2+ High Ki67
ER-, PR-, HER2- High Ki67

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with Luminal A type of breast carcinoma. Which of the following best describes the marker profile in her? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ER+, PR+, HER2- Low Ki67

 

  • Luminal A breast carcinoma is characterized by hormone receptor positivity and low proliferation rates. The expression profile typically includes estrogen receptor positive (ER+), progesterone receptor positive (PR+), and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 negative (HER2-). Additionally, this subtype is marked by a low Ki67 index, indicating a lower proliferation rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ER+, PR+, HER2- High Ki67: This combination, while similar in hormone receptor status, features a high Ki67 index, suggestive of a more aggressive subtype like Luminal B cancer.

 

Option C. ER+, PR+, HER2+ High Ki67: This profile describes a HER2-positive and high-proliferation subtype (often seen in more aggressive breast cancers).

 

Option D. ER-, PR-, HER2- High Ki67: Known as triple-negative breast cancer, this profile is markedly different from Luminal A as it lacks expression of ER, PR, and HER2, and is associated with higher grade tumors.

 

Educational objective:

 

Luminal A breast carcinoma is characterized by positive hormone receptors (ER and PR), absence of HER2 expression, and low Ki67 levels, indicative of a slower-growing, less aggressive tumor that typically has a better prognosis compared to other subtypes.

questions.text: In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled by?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mechanically

 

  • In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors show mechanical coupling involving structural interaction between the two.
  • Excitation-contraction coupling in both skeletal and cardiac muscle depends on structural and functional interactions between the voltage-sensing dihydropyridine receptor L-type Ca (2+) channels in the surface/transverse tubular membrane and ryanodine receptor Ca (2+) release channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane.
  • The channels are targeted to either side of a narrow junctional gap that separates the external and internal membrane systems and are arranged so that bi-directional structural and functional coupling can occur between the proteins. There is strong evidence for a physical interaction between the two types of channel protein in skeletal muscle.
  • It is thought to occur by a "mechanical coupling" mechanism involving protein-protein interactions that lead to activation of the sarcoplasmic reticulum ryanodine receptor by the voltage-sensing transverse (1-) tubule dihydropyridine receptor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemically: This would imply that the interaction is mediated by a chemical messenger, which is not the case for DHPR and RyR coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Option B. Electrically: Electrical coupling would imply that the interaction is mediated by an electric signal directly, which is not the mechanism in skeletal muscle.

 

Option C. Chemically and then electrically: This combination is incorrect as the coupling is purely mechanical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In skeletal muscle, the dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled mechanically, meaning their interaction and functional coupling rely on direct physical contacts between these protein structures to initiate muscle contraction.

questions.text: Structure made up of dense irregular collagen is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermis

 

Dermis (precisely Reticular dermis) is made up of dense irregular connective tissue. 

 

Irregular connective tissue, is characterized by collagen fibers that are randomly oriented in multiple directions.

 

Irregular connective tissue is of three types: Loose, Dense & Adipose.

 

Dense connective tissue can be found in areas where unsheathed organs are protected and where there is significant mechanical stress.

 

  • This arrangement of fibers provides strength and elasticity in multiple directions, allowing the skin to resist tearing.

 

Function: Provides structural integrity and support for the skin.

 

Dense connective tissue:

 

  • It typically exists in the reticular dermis.
  • Muscle and nerve sheaths made of the superficial connective tissue
  • Adventitia of large vessels
  • Capsules of various organs & glands (e.g.: testis sclera, periosteum, perichondrium)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligaments:

 

  • Composition: Primarily made up of dense regular connective tissue, which contains tightly packed collagen fibers that run in parallel directions.
  • Function: Connect bones to other bones.
  • Why it's not the answer: Ligaments have a more organized structure with the collagen fibers aligned in the same direction, which classifies them as dense regular connective tissue.

 

Option C. Tendons:

 

  • Composition: Made up of dense regular connective tissue, with collagen fibers that are closely packed and align in the same direction.
  • Function: Connect muscles to bones, aiding in the transmission of forces and movement.
  • Why it's not the answer: Like ligaments, tendons have collagen fibers that are organized in a parallel manner, making them dense regular connective tissue.

 

Option D. Bones:

 

  • Composition: Hard, dense connective tissue made up of cells (like osteocytes), as well as mineralized extracellular matrix containing collagen fibers and calcium phosphate.
  • Function: Provide structural support, protect vital organs, aid in movement, and store minerals.
  • Why it's not the answer: While bones do contain collagen, their primary structural component is the mineralized matrix which provides rigidity, distinguishing them from the dense irregular connective tissue of the dermis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reticular dermis is comprised of the dense irregular connective tissue, that plays a crucial role in providing structural support and integrity to the skin due to its randomly oriented collagen fibers, allowing the skin to resist tearing.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.34

Grays Anatomy: The anatomical basis of clinical practice- 42nd edition- page no 40, 41

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked green in the image below? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opponens pollicis

 

Explanation:

 

The palmar aspect of the first metacarpal is the area marked in the image. At this location, the opponens pollicis muscle inserts.

 

  • Opponens pollicis:
  • Origin: Crest of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.
  • Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.

 

The image below shows various intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor Pollicis Longus: Abductor pollicis longus is not directly attached to the first metacarpal. It originates from the posterior surface of the ulna and radius and inserts into the base of the first metacarpal bone. Its primary action is to abduct the thumb away from the palm.

 

Option B. Palmar Interossei: The palmar interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones in the palm of the hand. They are responsible for adducting the fingers toward the midline of the hand. They are not directly attached to the first metacarpal.

 

Option D. Flexor Pollicis Brevis: The flexor pollicis brevis muscle has two heads: the superficial head and the deep head. The superficial head originates from the flexor retinaculum, while the deep head originates from the trapezoid and capitate bones.

  • Both heads of the flexor pollicis brevis insert into the base of the first metacarpal bone.
  • The main action of the flexor pollicis brevis is to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The opponens pollicis muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the Crest of the trapezium bone. It inserts into the first metacarpal bone.
